comments.text:
+Rhiilynn
 There's no such thing as blue eye dominant. Blue eyes are always 
recessive. If your parents had blue eyed children, your dad carried a 
recessive gene. Brown will always mask blue if it's present, thus your 
father has brown eyes (He has one dominant brown allele, and one recessive 
blue allele). He passed the recessive allele to you and your sister, and he 
passed the dominant allele to your brother. Your mom (having blue eyes) can 
only pass recessive genes. You and your sister received, in total, two 
recessive blues, your brother received one recessive blue, and one dominant 
brown.

Genes always work the same way.
comments.author: LynneBat

comments.text:
The first part of what you said is true. But still, technically not ANY 
person can have a blue eyed child, because there are ways to find out if 
you are a carrier of that recessive allele. (Remember that each person only 
contributes one allele to their offspring, so, if that blue-eyed ancestor's 
CHILD didn't pass it on, it would never reappear further down the line)

Like Jayne said, you'd have to get genetic testing done to see if you carry 
the blue-eyed recessive trait. Genetic testing is how we can know for sure 
if you carry that trait. But what I mean is that you can't tell by looking 
at someone's appearance, or their family's appearance (i.e. their brown 
eyes) if they carry the trait. If you DON'T carry that recessive allele, 
you cannot have a blue-eyed child. But if you do carry that blue allele, 
even if you have brown eyes, there's the possibility of passing it on.

I feel like we've been talking ad nauseum haha You seem really interested 
in this, so I'd suggest finding a local science teacher (middle school, 
high school, college, doesn't really matter) and ask them to explain basic 
genetics to you -- specifically about genotypes, phenotypes and punnet 
squares.
 It's much easier to give visual examples in person than just walls of text.

comments.text:
In the most literal sense, if an entire family tree has only ever had 
dominant genes and none of them carried recessives, then you would be 
right. But just because an entire family has brown eyes, even generations 
and generations back, that doesn't mean they aren't carriers of recessive 
traits. Even if only one person in their family thousands of years ago had 
a recessive allele, even if it's been completely masked all these years, it 
is absolutely possible that it has been passed through every generation. 
There's no way for us to know for sure that every single person in a 
family's entire history has only had Dominant brown genes. In this person's 
case, we KNOW the father possessed a recessive allele BECAUSE he had 
children with blue eyes.

In genetics, there are "genotypes" and "phenotypes." Genotypes describe the 
genes a person carries. Phenotypes describe the physical appearance of 
those genes. All people who have brown eyes are either genotype Bb or BB, 
but they all still have brown eyes. Blue-eyed people are only bb. Each 
parent passes one allele to the offspring. If an entire family is genotype 
Bb, they still all have brown eyes, but they all carry a recessive blue 
allele. If the whole entire family has genotype BB, then there is no 
potential for them to have a blue-eyed child as they can only pass dominant 
genes. However, if they married someone with recessive genes, their 
children, even if they are brown-eyed, WILL be carriers of recessive genes 
because the blue-eyed partner can only pass recessive alleles.

So this person who has a dad whose "entire family" has brown eyes, and yet 
THEY have blue eyes is not an anomaly. Their father must've been genotype 
Bb, meaning somewhere in his family, other people with brown eyes also 
carried that recessive allele and passed it to him. Even if they only all 
ever married brown eyed people, any of them could've been carriers of 
recessive alleles, thus making this entirely reasonable and plausible.
comments.author: LynneBat

Even if her dad's whole family has brown eyes, it doesn't mean he doesn't

we can assume that her father only carried ONE dominant gene -- meaning his 
eyes are brown because the dominant masked the recessive. He just so 
happened to pass the recessive to 3 out of the 4 children. Because the 
mom's eyes are blue, she will always pass a recessive gene.

That situation is not an exception. It's a perfect example of the rule.

No. Scientifically speaking, it's still no: there is zero chance. (There 
could, I suppose, be some kind of freak mutation that negates the whole 
argument, but the reason we have these rules is because they have been 
observed and are reliable.) I say "statistical" because we're talking 
statistics, however, dominant alleles will always mask recessive ones. Of 
course, as others have mentioned, there are other factors in eye color, but 
when you're talking strictly Blue-Brown, if a person has only dominant 
alleles, their children will definitely (100% chance) have brown eyes.

Like all of us have mentioned, you have to know if a person is homo- or 
heterozygous to know FOR SURE what chances their offspring have of certain 
traits. If you are homozygous dominant brown, all of your children will 
have brown eyes. If you are heterozygous, (meaning one dominant trait and 
one recessive) and married to someone who is homozygous recessive blue, 
there is still only a 50% chance you will have a child with blue eyes. 
Again, ONLY if you already carry a recessive blue trait. If you don't carry 
that recessive trait, you're out of luck and you will not have a blue-eyed 
child.

It seems to me that you're just desperately trying to get someone to 
confirm for you that this person could have a blue-eyed child. You seem to 
really want that outcome.

comments.text:
This is a simplification and is not actually 100% true as there is at least 
one other gene in play, but we don't yet (as of the research I did a year 
and a half ago) know how the rest of it works, but the two genes that we 
know of are:
Either blue or green (green is dominant)
Either blue or brown (brown is dominant)
If you have the brown version, you will have brown eyes. If you do not have 
the brown version, but do have the green version, you will have green eyes.

A brown-eyed parent can "hide" recessive blue and green alleles which can 
be passed onto his or her offspring. A green-eyed parent could "hide" a 
recessive blue allele, which could be passed onto his or her offspring.

comments.author: Potato

comments.text:
+Potato
 Because in addition to having genes for green eyes, your mom is a carrier 
for blue eyes, and that just happens to be what trait was in the egg that 
was fertilized to make you. 50/50 chance for each blue and green. (Also, 
your brother then is a carrier for blue eyes, like your mom, since blue is 
the only color your father could have passed on.)

If you need, you can look up "punnett squares" for an explanation about how 
it works. Since I can't draw them on here, it would be a little weird to 
explain.
(Eye color is actually more complex than just that, but those will give you 
a decent understanding.)

comments.author: KillingSWE

comments.text:
A: Your father is heterozygous, which means that he has the blue eye allele 
and the brown eye allele. Because the brown eye allele is dominant, he has 
brown eyes. However, that does not mean that he has to pass on the brown 
eye allele. You are homozygous, which means that you have two blue eye 
alleles, one from your mother and one from your father.

comments.text:
All humans are related to each other. It is even possible to approximately 
date the matrilineal and patrilineal most recent common ancestors, meaning 
if you take everybody's mothers and then their mothers and then their 
mothers again and so forth, you finally and up with one woman from whom we 
all descend (sometimes called the mitochondrial Eve). Same goes for fathers 
(the Y-chromosomal Adam). However, both didn't live at the same time and 
weren't like a couple or anything. In fact, it's just a fluke of biology 
that we can date these two lines while others are more difficult. We have 
many more ancestors living at the same time as those most recent common 
ancestors. But still, we're all related on a timescale of 120,000 to 
150,000 years as all blue-eyed people are on that 10,000 year timescale. 
However, if you look for the absolute most recent common ancestor, that 
person probably lived a lot more recently actually, although this can only 
be modelled statistically.

If you are with a person that has at least a different skin color than 
yourself, chances are that your mutual most recent common ancestor is much 
younger than even those 10,000 years. If she's from the same reason you're 
most certainly distant cousins; I'd say no more than a couple of centuries 
apart ;) You can do a quick back-of-the-envelope calculation by considering 
that everyone has 2 parents, 4 grandparents, 8 great-grandparents, 16 
great-great-grandparents and so on, so 2^n ancestors in generation *n*. Now 
if you know what common area you and your partner are from and you know how 
many people live there and used to live there, you can get to a number of 
generations in which the number of ancestors is larger than the population 
of that area. What does that mean? Overlap in your family tree: people take 
multiple roles and the thing becomes a web. Of course, statistically this 
would have happened much, much earlier than that theoretical maximum.

comments.text:
Blue eyes do adapt slower but more completely to low light conditions where 
colors are less vibrant, but that probably isn't the explanation.  A 
different set of genes influence whether a person perceives patterns first 
or colors first, and this is associated with a variety of social and 
environmental conditions.  There is a higher percent occurrence of primary 
pattern recognition among blue-eyed people, which is associated with 
analytical personalities; whereas primary color-perception is more common 
among dark-eyed people.  This recognition priority is a separate trait that 
occurs in all populations, with only the proportion that varies.  Knowing 
one does not in any way guarantee the other.

Since architecture is a highly analytical profession, it may coincidentally 
contain more blue-eyed people than the population at large in some 
countries.  It would be more relevant in the USA or Britain than it would 
be in China, obviously.  It would take a rigorous statistical study to see 
if your intuition is accurate for your country.

There is a particular blue/gold pattern of eye coloration that is, in my 
experience, indicative of the pattern/analytic perception in the extreme, 
but that is apparently unreported in public science.  Maybe this is for the 
better.

So take black hair - recessive also, but no shortage of it depending on 
where you are - Africa, Asia, Middle East etc. Anywhere you get more 
diversity in the gene pool, you're less likely to see these recessive 
traits expressed. That's pretty simple science really. Black hair is better 
in sunnier climes, you can handle the heat and UV better, and your children 
are more likely to grow up healthily and choose mates that did the same. 
Also, never underestimate the power of sexual selection. That's a huge 
factor on gene prevalence too.

comments.text:
+Emo Puppy Okay, so when two people have a baby the baby gets the genes 
from both parents, but obviously the parents don't get to control which 
gene they give. It's random. Each gene the parent gives is called an 
allele. Two alleles make a gene (thats not 100% correct but its simple) for 
a trait. If your father had brown eyes and your mother had blue eyes then 
you were guaranteed to get a least one allele that is blue. Your mother had 
two blue alleles if she had blue eyes because the brown eye gene is 
dominant so if she had one blue and one brown then her eyes would have been 
brown. The dominant allele masks and takes over the recessive allele 
because the recessive allele is not the dominant one.
  
If your father had brown eyes but one of his parents had blue eyes than he 
has a blue allele. Because we know you have blue eyes we know that your 
father carries the blue allele its just masked by the brown one he also 
carries. 

When your parents made a baby, you, half of your alleles came from your 
father, half from your mother. They were carried to you in the egg and the 
sperm. Because there are so many little sperms, and each one carried a 
random collection of alleles, you could have had blue or brown eyes 
depending on which sperm got to the egg. The sperm that go to the egg had a 
blue eye allele combined with the blue eye allele from the egg means a blue 
eyed baby!

You just got lucky enough that the blue eye allele your father was carrying 
was the sperm that impregnated the egg.

I don't know which of your parents has which color eyes, but if I got it 
wrong and your father has blue eyes and your mother has brown than yeah 
just reverse the roles, the egg happened to have the blue eyed gene your 
mother was a carrier of and you were certain to get a blue one form your 
father's sperm.

Genetics is complicated, any questions?

If you are blue eyed you carry the phenotypes bb if you are brown eyed but 
carry the blue eyed gene then you have the phenotypes Bb and if you are 
brown eyed and only carry the brown eyed phenotypes then you are BB.
bb=blue
Bb=brown (carrying blue gene) 
BB=brown (not carrying blue gene)
If both parents are BB then their kid will be BB

brown allele from the other. This would make her eyes brown (because it's 
dominant). However, she would still possess the blue allele, and if she 
passed it down to you (50% chance), and your father passed down one of his 
blue alleles (his are both blue if he has blue eyes), you would have 2 blue 
alleles and blue eyes.

captions.text:
Despite the apparent prevalence of the trait
among swanky crooners and British spies and

creepy old creatures who just hung onto the
ring for too long, only about 8% of the world's

human population has blue eyes. Here in the
U.S. it's about twice that, but that's still

a lot less than it was at the turn of the
twentieth century when nearly half of all

Americans had the trait. So what happened?
Are blue-eyed humans going the way of the
dodo?

Well, no. We cleared up that rumor about redheads
going extinct; the same goes for blue eyes.

While the trait is becoming more rare, it's
unlikely it will disappear all together. Which

is crazy when you consider that 10,000 years
ago blue eyes didn't even exist. In fact,

there's a good chance that blue-eyed people
may all share one common ancestor. Studies

over the past decade have actually traced
the trait to a mutation that most likely arose

among brown-eyed people in a single human
in the Black Sea region of southeastern Europe
between 6,000 and 10,000 years ago.

The mutation affected what's known as the
OCA2 gene, which helps our bodies produce

melanin, the brownish pigment that gives color
to our hair and eyes and skin. The mutation

created kind of a dimmer switch for the pigmentation,
but it didn't affect the entire gene. Instead,

it only affected the production of melanin
in the iris, the ring structure around the
eye that regulates how much light gets in.

The bulk of the iris is a thick layer of melanin-producing
cells called the stroma. And the OCA2 mutation

turns the production of melanin in the stroma
way down, but the pigmentation still shows

up elsewhere, like in the hair and skin and
other parts of the iris. Basically, the mutation
keeps the stroma from being brown.

So why blue then? Well, strictly speaking,
blue eyes aren't actually blue. Instead, in

people with this mutation, the stroma is full
of nearly colorless cells. And when the light

strikes them, they scatter the wavelengths
back out, in a process similar to what makes

smoke or fog look blue when light passes through
them.

If there is some yellowish pigment in the
stroma, then the blue light will combine with

that to make green. Throw in a little bit
of brown, and you have hazel.

So how did we go from having no blue-eyed
people, to hundreds of millions of them in

less than 10 millennia? No one's entirely
sure why the trait spread so quickly through

Europe. Some scientists think the mutation
could have helped prevent certain eye disorders
related to long, dark northern winters.

But another factors appears to be that, for
whatever reason, lots of blue-eyed people

simply mated with other blue-eyed people in
the past, which kept the trait in circulation.

Because for each of your genes, you have two
different versions, called alleles, one from

your father and one from your mother. If you
have at least one dominant allele for a gene,
that's the trait you have.

The blue eyes come from a recessive allele,
which means if you inherit one allele for

blue eyes and another for brown, you're going
to have brown eyes. But you still carry the

recessive blue allele, which can be passed
on. Which means that that first person that

had that blue-eyed mutation didn't have blue
eyes. They had to pass that onto their children,

and their children had to pass it onto their
children, until eventually they came back

together to make someone with two blue-eyed
alleles.

When both parents have blue eyes, they both
have two recessive blue-eyed genes, which

means their children will also have blue eyes
since there's no dominant gene to mask the

recessive one. This is how you end up with
Scandinavian countries that are 95% blue-eyed,

and it also explains why the percentage of
blue eye-ers is dropping in much of the western
world.

Human populations are a lot more evenly spread
throughout the world than they were 10,000

years ago, so more blue eyes are pairing up
with brown eyes and producing brown-eyed offspring.

I wouldn't go so far as to call them endangered,
but safe to say those blue-eyed singers and
spies and Gollums will always be in the minority.

Thanks for watching this SciShow Dose. If
you'd like to help us keep exploring the world,

just go to subbable.com/scishow to find out
how you can become a supporter. And if you

want to keep getting smarter with us, don't
forget to go to youtube.com/scishow and subscribe.
